text.p: These are the leading stories in the Egyptian press on Tuesday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Arab unanimity is reached on recommending that normalisation with Israel stop, diplomatic bureaux be closed and boycott of the Jewish state be observed. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak sends letters to America, Russia and world leaders on the Arab League resolutions.
- Pope Shenouda of the Egyptian copts urges Egyptian christians not to visit Israel. During a visit to South Africa, the Pope says that latest Israeli practices are endangering the peace process.
- Industry Minister Soleiman Reda inspects iron ore mines near Aswan, 690 km(430 miles) south of Cairo. Indications show that reserves exceed 370 million tonnes, he says.
- Prime Minister Kamal Ganzouri says small-scale industries enjoy all exemptions provided by a new bill on investment guarantees and incentives.
- Investors and businessmen refuse the investment incentives bill. They told the parliament's economic committee yesterday that the bill contradicted with the Gatt agreement.

- A state of terror dominates the Cairo suburb of Qattamya after a wild beast, that looks like a dog, has attacked the area twice in two days and wounded seven people seriously. Police warned residents from going into streets after sunset. A similar beast killed and wounded about 17 people two months ago in south Egypt.
